entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
I need to comment on what the current version of datasphere, data products and Databricks really gives. It is not as "semantically rich and governed" as you may believe.

a) When you extract data from a CDS view the associated data are not coming through to Datasphere. Instead you rebuild them in Datasphere by extracting master data and text and then creating master data views that you then associated to your fact view. In you analytical model you choose which parts of the associated data you want to expose to the user.

b) Only data physically stored in the object store can be shared with databricks using data products. I.e. you copy your data to the object store. If you "copy" from the views created in a) you don't get your associated data in, i.e. no text on technical columns and no additional master data (i.e. not semantically rich). You will have to either build another view where you join master data and text to the view or you will have to create data product where you deliver these side tables as separate tables in the data product, including a how-to join things together description.

The idea of governed and semantically rich data is fine, but there is quite a long way before we are there. Not that I really mind as it could be hard to handle and understand a data set with fully exploded master data into the transactional data, it would be hundreds of columns without a clear link between source and column (e.g. is the procuct hiearchy coming from the transaction the product or the product compounded to sales organisation?). 

-Kristian

entry.title: Master Cloud Foundry Management in the SAP BTP Cockpit with Our New Tutorial Series
entry.content:
What You'll Learn

The Learn How to Manage Your Cloud Foundry Environment in the SAP BTP Cockpit series of 13 tutorials helps you master key tasks for managing your Cloud Foundry environment in the SAP BTP cockpit. These tutorials cover user management, application deployment, and monitoring, among other topics:

1. Getting Started with Cloud Foundry Environment and SAP BTP Cockpit
2. Understanding Spaces
3. Understanding Space Quotas
4. Managing Org Members
5. Managing Space Members
6. Deploying Applications
7. Managing Deployed Applications
8. Monitoring Applications and Spaces with Events and Logs
9. Managing Routes
10. Understanding Service Bindings
11. Understanding Environment Variables
12. Managing User-Provided Environment Variables
13. Understanding Security Groups

 

Getting Started

While the tutorials are designed to work best when completed in order, each one is also standalone. This means you can jump directly to topics that interest you most or address your immediate needs.

To help you practice, we've included two sample applications - one built with Node.js and another with Java. Download them from our GitHub repository, or feel free to use your own applications.

 

Need Help?

Running into any challenges? Don't hesitate to reach out. Drop your questions in the comments below, and we'll be happy to help.

Whether you're new to Cloud Foundry or looking to sharpen your skills, these tutorials will help you navigate the SAP BTP cockpit with confidence.

entry.title: 5th SIBS Partners Meeting: Innovation with connectivity: SIBS with SAP
entry.content:
Last Thursday, I had the pleasure of participating,  in the 5th SIBS Partners Meeting, held at Quinta da Atela, in Alpiar√ßa. Once again, the event proved to be a key moment for knowledge sharing, strategic alignment, and strengthening the partner ecosystem around SIBS and its technologies.

This fifth edition reinforced the focus on collaboration, technological innovation and future vision, while also bringing new and highly relevant topics to the forefront ‚Äî particularly the real impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) on partner products, business models and go-to-market strategies.

Two panels, one shared goal: creating value

The event featured two discussion panels, both offering strong practical and strategic insights.

The first panel focused on the relationship between SIBS and its partners, addressing:

  • Different interaction models with SIBS

  • Real examples of products and solutions built on SIBS technologies

  • Technical, operational and integration challenges in real market contexts

This discussion clearly highlighted the maturity of the partner ecosystem and the importance of a collaborative approach to accelerate innovation while ensuring secure, scalable and reliable solutions.

The second panel was dedicated to Artificial Intelligence in partner products, fostering an open and pragmatic discussion around:

  • Security challenges related to the adoption of AI

  • The impact of AI on product value propositions

  • Commercial challenges and opportunities, including how AI can drive differentiation, sales growth and new business models

It became evident that AI is no longer just a technological topic, but a strategic business driver, requiring the right balance between innovation, trust, compliance and commercial viability.

Recognition for  SAP‚ÄìSIBS interface award

For me, one of the most significant moments of the event was the recognition given to Makevalue, which I represented, that received an award for the SAP‚ÄìSIBS interface developed throughout 2025. I participated in this project in 2025, and it was a game-changer in terms of knowledge sharing and a comprehensive approach to product development: purpose, security, technology, sales, and marketing.

This project was a key enabler for the official certification of SAP/SIBS connectivity by SIBS, representing an important milestone in the integration between SAP systems and the SIBS payments and services ecosystem.

The solution was developed within the scope of a SIBS LABS project, further underlining its innovative nature and the strong collaboration between the technical and functional teams involved.

This recognition reinforces Makevalue‚Äôs commitment to:

  • Deliver robust, certified and enterprise-grade solutions

  • Enable seamless integration between core business platforms such as SAP and critical market infrastructures

  • Actively contribute to the evolution of the national and international technology ecosystem

Conclusion

The 5th SIBS Partners Meeting once again confirmed that the future is built on strong partnerships, continuous innovation and the responsible adoption of emerging technologies, particularly Artificial Intelligence. For the partners, this event was a moment of pride, exchange and strategic alignment, reinforcing our role as a trusted technology partner in complex integration and innovation projects

We remain fully committed to creating value, now strengthened by a recognition that reflects consistent work, close collaboration and a long-term vision.

entry.title: SAC Planning: Keep value unchanged when writing from higher to lower granularity
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I‚Äôm working with a planning-enabled model in SAP Analytics Cloud. On top of this model I built a Story with two tables. Both tables are based on the same model.

Setup

  • Table A contains the measure ‚ÄúKonditionswert (PLAN) Vorbelegung‚Äù (pre-fill / default value).

  • Table B contains the measure ‚ÄúKonditionswert (PLAN)‚Äù (plan value).

Both tables use the following dimensions in the rows:

  1. Account system owner (Kontosysteminhaber)

  2. Account system product (Kontosystemprodukt)

  3. Account system ID (Kontosystem-ID)

  4. Product (Produkt)

Table B additionally includes the dimension ‚ÄúAccount (IBAN)‚Äù.
So Table A shows data on account-system-ID level, while Table B is more detailed on account (IBAN) level.

A single account system can have multiple accounts assigned to it, and each account belongs to exactly one account system.

What I‚Äôm trying to achieve

I want users to plan values in the ‚ÄúPre-fill‚Äù measure. For example, they enter 12 in Table A.
I created a Data Action that copies values from ‚ÄúPre-fill‚Äù into ‚ÄúPlan‚Äù when executed.

My goal is:
When a user enters a value in Pre-fill, the exact same value should be written into Plan (without changing it).

The problem

Because Table A is at account-system level and Table B is at account level, when I run the Data Action the value is automatically distributed evenly across the accounts.

Example:
If I enter 12 for account system ID 12345, which has 2 accounts, then SAC writes 6 into Plan for each account instead of writing 12.

What I need

I want to allow a pre-fill on account-system level that is then applied to the individual accounts, so users don‚Äôt have to plan each account manually.

What do I need to do so that when posting a number in Table A (account-system level), the number is written to Table B (account level) without being split, i.e. the value should be copied as-is?

Thanks a lot for any help!

Best regards,
Niklas

entry.title: is IBD partial automatic packing possible?
entry.content:
Hello,

We have no ASN in this implementation so HU's will either be created automatically via packing specification and/or manually.

So, the scenario might be this one:

Several similar products are packed the same way: let's say the "outer box" contains 10 "inner boxes" of 10 units (outer box, 100un).

outer boxes are hu managed and stored on a hu managed storage type. inner boxes or "loose units" are not hu managed and stored on a non-hu managed storage type.

Skipping the discussion of order quantities, we might receive one inbound delivery as such:

- material#1, 103ea (1 outer box + 3 loose units)

- material#2, 108ea (1 outer box + 8 loose units)

- material#3, 140ea (1 outer box + 4 inner boxes)

the physical packing delivered by the supplier is:

- hu#1, material#1, 100ea --> moving to stg.type#1

- hu#2, material#2, 100ea --> moving to stg.type#1

- hu#3, material#3, 100ea --> moving to stg.type#1

- hu#4, material#1, 3ea + material#2, 8ea + material#3, 40ea --> moving to stg.type#2

so, when packing this IBD i would expect that automatic packing was able to partially pack each item, creating Hu#1, Hu#2, HU#3 and leave the remaining quantity unpacked; that unpacked quantity would be packed to hu#4 on receiving.

but automatic packing is on error, requiring to fully pack each item (and in the end, no packing at all) and i don't what might be the best solution to overcome this error.

is there a way to only partial pack what is covered by the packing specification?

should i leave a final level to pack all the remaining quantities?

is there a way to propose that final hu#4, mixing all loose quantities? (even so, since this is manually - eventually randomly - packed at the vendor, would we benefit anything by doing so?)

thank you for your insights,

best regards

entry.title: Re: Customizing the Company Profitability Review Booklet in Margin Analysis
entry.content:
Hello @roman_rapp , thank you for the update, very interesting. üòÄ

Could you provide more information about the Filter: CurrencyField ?

This seems to be brand new because i have not seen anything like that. So far SAP provides an analytical app often in only one fix currency e.g. AmountInGlobalCurrency or AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency or AmountInTransactionCurrency and then all restricted measures are depend on it. Other apps provide measures in two or more CurrencyCodes but the number of measures is often limited to a small number to avoid confusion for the enduser, if all measures double or triple.

I tried to solve it by using an Extended view and join "CurrencyRole"

association [1..1] to C_LedgerCompanyCodeCrcyRoles as _CurrencyRole on $projection.ledger  = _CurrencyRole.Ledger
                                                                   and $projection.companycode  = _CurrencyRole.CompanyCode

 An in the analytical projection view

...
// On Demand Parameter to choose Company Code or Group Currency 
    @Consumption.defaultValue: '30'
    @EndUserText.label: 'Choose Currency (10/30), please'
    P_CurrencyRole                 : abap.numc( 2 ),
...
  //// Test for Gross sales from SD with CurrencyRole ////

  @EndUserText.label: 'Gross Sales Custom Price 30'
  @AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #ROWS
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'GlobalCurrency'
  @Aggregation.default: #SUM
  case when SemanticTag = 'ZGS_C_PRIC'
  and GlobalCurrencyRole = $parameters.P_CurrencyRole          // 30 fix
  then curr_to_decfloat_amount ( AmountInGlobalCurrency )
  else null
  end                                                                                                            as GrossSalesCustomPriceGlobCurr,


  @EndUserText.label: 'Gross Sales Custom Price 10'
  @AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #ROWS
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'CompanyCodeCurrency'
  @Aggregation.default: #SUM
  case when SemanticTag = 'ZGS_C_PRIC'
  and CompanyCodeCurrencyRole = $parameters.P_CurrencyRole     // 10 fix
  then curr_to_decfloat_amount ( AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency )
  else null
  end                                                                                                            as GrossSalesCustomPriceCCCurr,

  //// Test for Gross sales from SD with CurrencyRole ////

This worked somehow, but the result is that one of two measures is always "initial" and remained in the report as an "empty row". I then used Annotation @Analytics.settings.zeroValues but this also removes other "empty rows" that i don¬¥t want to remove.

The issues lies in the fact, that "all measures are part of the measure structure" and "there can only be one measure structure". So my thoughts are: Why can¬¥t there be two measure structure, one for "GroupCurrency" and one for "CompanyCodeCurreny" that can be choosen on the selection screen of a query?

While a second measure structure would fix the appearance in the query (only measures with CCC or GroupCry would show), what is not solved are the consequences in the CDS View. The CDS View would become significantly larger. See my code except. Same Semantic Tag but, same text ("Gross Sales Custom Price") but the issues lies within 

then curr_to_decfloat_amount ( AmountInGlobalCurrency )

then curr_to_decfloat_amount ( AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency )

 

So long story short. How does CurrencyField work in the given example?

Thank you, regards

David

entry.title: Re: EWM: How is the Quantity field of an HU derived?
entry.content:
Hi, i found the answer.

Get HU GUID from table /SCWM/HUHDR and /SCWM/HUREF and cross-reference it with /SCWM/GMHUREF. From /SCWM/GMHUREF table, get the corresponding HU Logs, then use the HU logs to query the quantity from table /SCWM/GMHUITM.

entry.content:

In SAP Analytics Cloud (Import Model), my sales data contains only one time dimension (Created On).

For promotion analysis, I need to compare sales before, during, and after a selected promotion. These periods are not fixed and must be dynamically derived from the promotion‚Äôs start and end dates. All periods should remain aligned to the selected promotion and be evaluated simultaneously.

I‚Äôm trying to understand whether SAP Analytics Cloud supports this type of analysis using dynamic date filters or restricted measures on a single date dimension, or if this is a known limitation.

I‚Äôm open to alternative or recommended approaches in SAC, such as:

  • using advanced formulas instead of restricted measures

  • introducing helper dimensions or flags

  • separating promotion metadata into a dedicated model

  • or restructuring the story/model if needed

Any best-practice guidance or design recommendations would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: New ESAC (CQC) Pilot Deployment Readiness for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub
entry.content:
Big news! Starting in Q1 2026, SAP Enterprise Support will launch a new pilot Continuous Quality Check (CQC) Deployment Readiness for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub through the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC).

 

This new CQC supports customers in reviewing configuration required to successfully deploy and adopt SAP Signavio Process Manager and SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub.

Watch this short introduction to the CQC Deployment Readiness for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub
 

Scope

Organizations need trusted, efficient tools to model, share, and govern business processes across the enterprise.
This CQC helps customers confidently deploy SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub by ensuring all technical prerequisites, workspace configuration steps, and governance options are in place before the rollout.

Through this pilot engagement, you will receive guided support to:

  • Prepare your SAP Signavio workspace for modeling and collaboration
  • Validate required system connections and technical configurations
  • Ensure Collaboration Hub visibility, navigation, and governance settings align with organizational needs
  • Establish an environment where teams can quickly begin modeling, publishing, and reviewing processes in a shared workspace

This CQC is ideal for organizations seeking to accelerate SAP Signavio adoption and ensure a smooth, secure, and compliant deployment from day one.

As part of this CQC, SAP Enterprise Support experts will provide:

  • Technical validation of prerequisites required for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub
  • Guidance and verification of workspace setup, including user access, attributes, modeling subsets, security settings, and folder structures
  • A final summary report outlining findings, configuration results, and recommendations

This ensures your teams begin with a solid technical foundation that supports consistent, compliant, and scalable process modeling and collaboration.
This CQC can be requested after customers complete the Expert Guided Implementations for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub.

Prerequisites

To ensure a smooth onboarding process, customers should have:

  • Valid licenses for:
    • SAP Signavio Process Manager
    • SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub
  • A set‚Äëup SAP Signavio workspace that includes Process Manager and Collaboration Hub
  • Appropriate user roles and access assigned for administrators and modelers
  • Any internal modeling conventions or audience‚Äëspecific requirements ready for deployment support

Outcome

After completing this CQC, you will have:

  • Clear validation on your SAP Signavio Collaboration Hub and Process Manager environment
  • Clear guidance on governance, modeling conventions, and administrative settings
  • A final report summarizing deployment readiness and recommended improvements
  • Confidence that your teams can begin modeling, sharing, and collaborating effectively and securely

Participation

  • This pilot is offered through the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC).
  • To learn more about ESAC, visit the program website.

To register your interest, please contact us at: esac@sap.com
(Include your location or time zone and mention your interest in this pilot workstream.)

entry.title: SAP Financial Consolidation - Running two consolidations
entry.content:
Hi All,

In SAP Financial Consolidation, is there a way to run two consolidations, one for a small group, and another for the whole group which includes this smaller group? 

We currently have one consolidation for the whole group in place, and now need to set up a smaller group within this whole group and also have a consolidation for these selected entities within this group for statutory reporting purpose. 

I'm looking at the Consolidation definitions and Intercompany reconciliation definitions. My initial thought was to create the similar consolidation definition but applying for this smaller group. The existing definitions for the whole group would remain unchanged.

Then I notice there is an option for Different variant for subconsolidations, and Secondary scope. If I tick those two, with the defined smaller group, would this then apply the existing rules for the smaller group, as well as the whole group? 

In the above either way, would it create duplicated elimination journals, that we have two consolidations and some may overlap? 

If anyone has experience on this, I would be much appreciated if you could share your thoughts here - many thanks! 

SAP BusinessObjects Financial Consolidation @ErvinSzolke  @SAPExpert

entry.title: Re: Telegram NOT created for WT
entry.content:
Hi,

you should check the SMQR as well as the SMQ2 for possible stuck queues. The WT-DET can be triggered manually as you did but normally should be triggered automatically when ever you create a new HU-WT with subsystem relevance "Y" or confirm/cancel one. This is done by the system in the background and will be executed as a queue. So please check the SMQR if you have entries there. Either you need a very generic entry like this to trigger all queues:

or more specific entry to trigger only your relevant WT-DET-Queues.

If the queue is registered within the SMQR but still not executed manually check the SMQ2 for some possible stuck entries for PLC/MFS-Resource.

entry.title: How to generate sitemap index file in OCC implementation in Hybris (SAP commerce)
entry.content:
We‚Äôre on version 2211.45 and have configured sitemap media jobs for our site (PDP pages). When we run the job, it correctly generates multiple sitemap media files (product-en-usd-1-12346716051403148239.xml, product-en-usd-2-15922516307997787283.xml etc.) and attaches them to the BaseSite, as expected.

However, it doesn‚Äôt generate a sitemap index file. We need an index file that references all the generated sitemap media files.

Is there an out-of-the-box (OOTB) way to generate the sitemap index file?

In Old accelerator implementation, there is an endpoint /sitemap.xml which would display index file that referencing to generated sitemap files. Since we are using OCC based implementation, we can't use it. Right now, we‚Äôve built a custom solution that creates the index file by reading the references to the generated sitemap files.

Please let me know if there is any OOTB solution/provision for sitemap index file generation.

entry.title: Re: Customizing the Company Profitability Review Booklet in Margin Analysis
entry.content:
Hi David,

we have the Currency filter in all our booklets in Margin Analysis, so e.g. also in the Product Profitability and Project Financial booklets. This way you can display several currencies in parallel, also the Functional one, which would not work, if we had duplicated the full measure strcuture for each currency..

I am not the technical expert, but you can check the underlying CDS view C_COMPANYMARGINQUERY_2 and the underlying cube I_CompanyMarginCube_2 to see how it works technically. Both are C1 released, so you should be able to see them.

We have a dedicated view for the currency field:

define view entity I_CompanyMarginCurrencyField as select from I_CurrencyField {

@ObjectModel.text.association: '_Text'

key CurrencyField,

_Text

}

where CurrencyField = 'CCC'

or CurrencyField = 'GC'

or CurrencyField = 'FC'

 

which is used in the cube:

 

define view entity I_CompanyMarginCube_2

as select from I_GLAcctLineItemSemTagGLAcct as I_GLAcctLineItemSemTagGLAcct

 

association [0..1] to I_CompanyMarginCurrencyField as _CurrencyField on _CurrencyField.CurrencyField = $projection.CurrencyField

 

Then there is some cast logic in the cube, which you can copy to your needs.

 

I hope this helps.

 

Best regards,

Roman

entry.title: Re: /SCWM/MFS_SIM_RECEIVE not working - no Telegram sent
entry.content:
Hi,

I was wondering for which telegram type you try to use the simulation. Within the MFS-Customizing you can define fine them (see Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Interfaces  Material Flow System (MFS)  Telegram Processing  Define Telegram Structure.)

 

The simulations works as it detects the telegram type that was "sent" (for example warehouse tasks) and therefore needs to send the telegram type warehouse task confirmation as an answer:

So therefore you want to use the simulation for the telegram type WT you also need to maintain the expected answer telegram WT-Confirmation within the customizing.

As you can see from the screenshot of the SAP-coding the simulation is kind a limited. So for example if you use the case conveyer system within your project you can not use the /SCWM/MFS_SIM_RECEIVE for the expected answers as within the CASE-Statement no telegram types for the case conveyers telegram types are foreseen.  In this case you would need to copy this FM and adjust it as needed.

entry.title: WalkMe Learning Arc: Die Zukunft des KI-gest√ºtzten Lernen
entry.content:
WalkMe Learning Arc stellt einen Paradigmenwechsel im digitalen Lernen dar und bietet einen umfassenden Einblick in die innovative KI-gest√ºtzte Lernl√∂sung auf der WalkMe-Plattform. Mike Fritz (SAP) und Kristina Kunad (SAP) demonstrierten in einer Session am 21.1. die neue Generation des digitalen Lernens, das nahtlos in Arbeitsanwendungen integriert wird und automatisch personalisierte Lerninhalte erstellt. 

WalkMe Learning Arc

WalkMe Learning Arc positioniert sich als inoffizieller Nachfolger von SAP Enable Now im Kontext des digitalen Lernens und bringt alle Funktionalit√§ten nativ auf die WalkMe-Plattform. Das System ist KI-nativ konzipiert und nutzt Sprachmodelle wie bspw. Google Gemini f√ºr die Content-Erstellung und Medienanalyse. Diese AI-First-Herangehensweise erm√∂glicht es, aus beliebigen Materialien wie Bildern, PDFs oder reinen Texten automatisch Rohger√ºste f√ºr fertigen Lerncontent zu generieren.

Revolution√§res Content Authoring mit KI-Unterst√ºtzung

Das Content Authoring erfolgt √ºber einen modernen Editor mit Endless Scroll-Navigation (statt des bisherigen seitenbasierten PowerPoint-Ansatzes bei SAP Enable Now). Die KI kann aus hochgeladenen Dokumenten und Screenshots automatisch Kursinhalte generieren und dabei didaktisch sinnvolle Platzhalter f√ºr Systemsimulationen erstellen. Diese Platzhalter enthalten bereits Storyboards f√ºr Autor:innen und zeigen auf, wo aus didaktischer Perspektive praktische √úbungen sinnvoll w√§ren.

 

Praktische Demonstration der KI-gest√ºtzten Content-Generierung

Mike Fritz demonstrierte live die KI-Funktionalit√§t, indem er das System anwies, einen Kurs √ºber das SAP Fiori Launchpad zu erstellen. Dabei sollte die KI aus bereitgestellten Assets einen Kurs generieren, im Internet nach zus√§tzlichen Informationen suchen und Platzhalter f√ºr Systemsimulationen an didaktisch sinnvollen Stellen einf√ºgen. Das System sollte au√üerdem Storyboards f√ºr Autor:innen erstellen, die zeigen, wo in einem solchen Curriculum noch Simulationen zu erzeugen sind und was aufgezeichnet werden soll.

Die praktische Demonstration zeigte, wie aus PDF-Dokumenten und Screenshots zum SAP Fiori Launchpad automatisch ein vollst√§ndiger Kurs generiert wurde. Nach dem Upload fragt das System, ob die Assets in den jeweiligen Kursen als Assets verwendet oder nur als Wissensbasis dienen sollen.

WalkMe Learning Arc extrahiert Informationen aus PDFs, platziert Screenshots an geeigneten Stellen und erstellt didaktisch aufbereitete Inhalte. Wie Mike Fritz betonte, wurden alle Informationen von WalkMe Learning Arc generiert, ohne dass manuell ein einziger Buchstabe ge√§ndert werden musste. Die Simulationsplatzhalter enthalten konkrete didaktische Anweisungen, die aus der Sicht des hinterlegten Modells nach jedem Kapitel praktische √úbungen vorschlagen.

Die Benutzeroberfl√§che ist bewusst schlank und intuitiv gestaltet - Mike Fritz beschrieb sie als sehr intuitiv und nicht so schwerf√§llig wie SAP Enable Now. √úber Pluszeichen oberhalb oder unterhalb fokussierter Objekte k√∂nnen neue Inhalte hinzugef√ºgt werden, alternativ per Drag and Drop. AI Writing Assistance steht auch f√ºr das weitere Editieren nach der initialen Generierung zur Verf√ºgung - die KI-Unterst√ºtzung beschr√§nkt sich nicht nur auf die erste Content-Erstellung.

Simulationserstellung und Interaktivit√§t

Die Simulationserstellung erfolgt √ºber eine Browser-Extension, die Screenshots in beliebigen Applikationen aufnehmen kann. W√§hrend der Aufzeichnung k√∂nnen Schritte gel√∂scht, die Aufzeichnung neu gestartet oder pausiert werden - Features, wie sie auch SAP Enable Now angeboten hat.

Simulationsaufzeichnung funktioniert technisch √§hnlich wie der SAP Enable Now Web Recorder und nutzt eine Browser-Extension f√ºr die Aufzeichnung beliebiger Screens. Dabei wurde die Objekterkennung grundlegend modernisiert: Statt der starren Profillogik von SAP Enable Now analysieren die AI-Bildanalysefunktionen die einzelnen erfassten Screenshots. Wie Mike Fritz erkl√§rte, wird die Objektinformation nicht mehr so starr wie bisher √ºber ein Glossar und eine Objekterkennungslogik erzeugt, sondern von der Bildanalyse der KI √ºbernommen. Das OCR und die Screen Recognition der verwendeten KI-Modelle analysiert die einzelnen erfassten Screenshots, interpretiert sie sofort und l√§sst R√ºckschl√ºsse auf die zugrundeliegende Applikation und das Objekt zu, mit dem interagiert wurde. Man ben√∂tigt also keine Skripte mehr f√ºr jede Anwendung - die KI-gest√ºtzte Objekterkennung macht die Aufzeichnung universell einsetzbar.

Bisher ist die Aufnahme nur im Browser m√∂glich. F√ºr Desktop-Applikationen gibt es momentan keine direkte Aufnahmem√∂glichkeit √ºber WalkMe Learning Arc, jedoch k√∂nnen zumindest bestehende SAP Enable Now Kund:innen, die auf WalkMe Learning Arc umsteigen, weiterhin mit dem SAP Enable Now Producer Desktop-Applikationen aufzeichnen. Diese Funktionalit√§t bleibt vollst√§ndig erhalten und erm√∂glicht die nahtlose Weiternutzung bestehender Desktop-Aufzeichnungskapazit√§ten.

Die erstellten Simulationen unterst√ºtzen aktuell zwei Modi: Practice Mode und Demo Mode. Der Test-Modus wird mit einem der n√§chsten Release geliefert.
Im aktuellen Release sind die beiden Abspielmodi verf√ºgbar, die gem√§√ü Kundenbefragung als die am h√§ufigsten verwendeten identifiziert wurden. F√ºr jeden Modus k√∂nnen spezifische Eigenschaften wie Ablaufzeit, Delay pro Schritt und Feedback-Texte konfiguriert werden.

Texteingaben in Simulationen funktionieren weiterhin. Die Bearbeitung von Simulationen erfolgt in einer vertrauten Umgebung mit einzelnen Schritten, Interaktionsbeschreibungen und der M√∂glichkeit zur Anpassung von Design-Elementen wie bspw. Farben und Rahmen. Zus√§tzliche Objekte wie Balloons (fr√ºher Bubbles), Pfeile, Highlights und geometrische Formen k√∂nnen eingef√ºgt werden.

F√ºr Simulationen k√∂nnen Handouts generiert werden - verschiedene Ausgabem√∂glichkeiten stehen zur Verf√ºgung, wie in der Demonstration gezeigt wurde.

Erweiterte Funktionalit√§ten in WalkMe Learning Arc und Barrierefreiheit

WalkMe Learning Arc bietet umfassende Unterst√ºtzung f√ºr verschiedene Content-Typen: klassischer Text, Bilder, physisch hochgeladene Videos (MP4 und andere Formate), Screen Recordings und interaktive Simulationen.

Ein herausragendes Feature ist die automatische Generierung von Alternativtexten f√ºr Screenreader zur Barrierefreiheit. Mit einem Klick analysiert die KI Bilder und generiert beschreibende Texte, wodurch Content schnell barrierefrei gestaltet werden kann. Diese Funktionalit√§t wurde in der Demonstration als besonders wertvoll f√ºr die praktische Anwendung hervorgehoben.

Das integrierte Lernportal bietet KI-basierte Suchfunktionen, die nicht nur Titel und Eigenschaften, sondern tats√§chlich im Content suchen. Dies eliminiert die Notwendigkeit f√ºr umfangreiche Keyword- und Synonym-Listen, da das System intuitiv versteht, was Lernende suchen. Das Portal unterst√ºtzt aktuell f√ºnf UI-Sprachen f√ºr Endanwender:innen und bietet eine ebenfalls KI-gest√ºtzte √úbersetzungsfunktionen f√ºr Contents in eine beliebige Zielsprache.

Technische Details und Content-Management

Das Content-Management erfolgt √ºber ein modern gestaltetes Ablagesystem, in dem alle Inhalte kommentiert und mit Co-Autor:innen geteilt werden k√∂nnen. Ein Publish/Unpublish-Funktion sorgt daf√ºr, dass Inhalte erst nach expliziter Freigabe f√ºr Endanwendende zug√§nglich sind. Das Publizierungsrecht ist ein explizites Recht, das bestimmten Autorengruppen besitzen.

Zusammenarbeit in WalkMe funktioniert bereits gut f√ºr die gemeinsame Bearbeitung von Inhalten - mehrere Autor:innen k√∂nnen nacheinander an derselben Simulation arbeiten. Strikte Workflows wie in SAP Enable Now sind momentan noch nicht m√∂glich.

Analytics und kontextsensitive Auslieferung

Die Kontextsensitivit√§t wird durch die WalkMe-Komponente ‚ÄûWalkMe Menu‚Äú gew√§hrleistet, die Lerninhalte genau dann ausliefert, wenn sie ben√∂tigt werden. Das WalkMe-Men√º √ºbernimmt dabei die Rolle des fr√ºheren SAP Companions.

Die Segmentierung und zielgruppenspezifische Auslieferung funktioniert flexibler als in SAP Enable Now, da zus√§tzlich mit JavaScript-Variablen und APIs von Ziel-Applikationen gearbeitet werden kann. Einzelne Lerninhalte k√∂nnen mit spezifischen Segmenten verkn√ºpft werden, wobei Kriterien wie Abteilungen, Lokalisationen oder andere Eigenschaften verwendet werden k√∂nnen.

WalkMe Learning Arc bietet umfassende Analytics-Funktionen mit flexibel anpassbaren Reports und APIs f√ºr die Integration mit bspw. bestehende Dashboards.
Der Learning Overview zeigt detaillierte Statistiken √ºber Nutzung, Startrate und Completion Rate einzelner Inhalte. Alle Daten k√∂nnen DSGVO-konform anonymisiert werden. Das Reporting ist sehr granular, ebenso die Berechtigungen, wobei an beiden Aspekten kontinuierlich weiterentwickelt wird.

Digital Adoption Plattform-Funktionen

Die Digital Adoption Plattform von WalkMe erm√∂glichen parametrisierte und zielgerichtete Auslieferung von Lernvarianten basierend auf Verhaltensmustern einzelner User:innen. Dabei k√∂nnen geografische Standorte und Prozessvarianten mit entsprechenden Lernvorgaben verkn√ºpft werden. Diese Funktionalit√§t geht weit √ºber das hinaus, was mit SAP Enable Now m√∂glich war.

WalkMe als Weltmarktf√ºhrer im Digital Adoption Platform-Bereich bringt hier erweiterte M√∂glichkeiten mit. Die Standardisierung von Arbeitsprozessen und die subjektive F√ºhrung einzelner Mitarbeitenden werden durch das Thema digitales Lernen erweitert.

Ein wichtiger Aspekt f√ºr Kund:innen ist die Frage nach eigenen LLMs: Momentan ist die Integration eigener Large Language Models nur auf WalkMe-Papier m√∂glich, SAP bietet dieses Modell generell nicht an.

Nahtlose Migration: Von SAP Enable Now zu WalkMe Learning Arc

Die Teilnehmenden zeigten besonders gro√ües Interesse an der Frage bestehender SAP Enable Now Inhalte., v.a. auf der nahtlosen Migration von SAP Enable Now Lern-Content. Die digitalen Lerninhalte - Simulationen, Kurse, Handb√ºcher und Quick Reference Cards - werden technisch nach WalkMe Learning Arc √ºberf√ºhrt und bleiben dort einschr√§nkungslos weiter bearbeitbar. Der SAP Enable Now Producer bleibt f√ºr fr√ºhere SAP Enable Now Kunden als Bearbeitungskomponente innerhalb von WalkMe Learning Arc auch nach Beendigung der SAP Enable Now Subskription verf√ºgbar und wird bis 2030 garantiert unterst√ºtzt.

Detaillierte Migrationserfahrung aus der Demonstration:

Mike Fritz demonstrierte den Migrationsprozess live und erkl√§rte, dass es drei S√§ulen gibt. ‚ÄûHostable‚Äú bedeutet, dass einzelne SAP Enable Now Workspaces eins-zu-eins auf die WalkMe-Plattform kopiert werden. Dies geschieht ohne Beratungsaufwand und im Hintergrund.

 

 

‚ÄûEditable‚Äú: Wenn Worspaces/Workareas nach WalkMe kopiert wurden, k√∂nnen die Inhalte dort weiterhin vollst√§ndig mit dem SAP Enable Now Producer bearbeitet werden - sie stehen nicht nur zur Ansicht zur Verf√ºgung.

‚ÄûPlayable‚Äú: Mike zeigte konkret einen migrierten SAP S/4HANA Asset Accounting Workspace, mit 123 Simulationen, einem Video und einer einf√ºhrenden Buchseite, die nach WalkMe √ºberf√ºhrt worden war. Der Migrationsprozess kopierte die Daten eins-zu-eins im Hintergrund und informiert √ºber ein Notifikationsfenster, wenn der Prozess abgeschlossen ist. Danach steht exakt der gleiche Baum zur Verf√ºgung, wobei die Strukturen eins-zu-eins identisch sind und die Daten physisch √ºberf√ºhrt wurden.

Die praktische Integration in neue WalkMe Learning Arc Kurse wurde demonstriert: Mike Fritz zeigte, wie eine √úbung aus dem migrierten Content in einem WalkMe Learning Arc-Kurs eingebaut werden kann und wie √ºberf√ºhrte SAP Enable Now Objekte jeden Typs im WalkMe Lernportal angezeigt werden.

Flexible Migrationsstrategie

Mike Fritz erl√§uterte die strategischen Optionen: Die Migration kann als Chance gesehen werden, um aufzur√§umen und nur noch das zu migrieren, was noch aktuell ist. Danach k√∂nnen die einzelnen Einsprungpunkte in die Lernbibliotheken in das modernere WalkMe Lernportal eingebaut werden, ohne dass Contents neu erstellt werden m√ºssen. Es m√ºssen nicht zwingend einzelne Modi (die unterste Ebene) verbaut werden. Es kann ein Sprung in ein ganzes Simulationsobjekt oder eine ganze Bibliothek verbaut werden.

Integration und Ausbildung

Die Export-Funktionalit√§ten sind in der ersten Version noch reduziert, aber werden kontinuierlich erweitert. Aktuell gibt es ein standardisiertes PDF-Dokumentationsformat, das der SAP Enable Now Standarddokumentation stark √§hnelt, mit den zus√§tzlichen Texten, die von der KI erzeugt wurden, auch auf Kursebene.

Die Integration mit SAP SuccessFactors Learning √ºber SCORM Ex- und Import wird erst in einer sp√§teren Version m√∂glich sein.  F√ºr alle, die auch in der Live Session waren: Bitte beachtet, dass dies in der Live Session von Mike anders kommuniziert wurde. 

F√ºr die Ausbildung von Autoren und Administratoren gibt es verschiedene Kurse auf learning.sap.com, bereits nach WalkMe selektiert und der WalkMe-eigenen Schulungsplattform. Dazu ist vorab eine Anmeldung n√∂tig. 

Verf√ºgbarkeit und Roadmap

WalkMe Learning Arc ist seit Anfang Dezember in der ersten Version verf√ºgbar (General Availability). Die Entwicklung erfolgte in beeindruckender Geschwindigkeit - innerhalb von nur einem Jahr entwickelten die beiden Teams gemeinsam diese umfassende L√∂sung.

Weiterf√ºhrende Roadmap-Items k√∂nnen aktuell nicht genau terminiert werden.

Bez√ºglich WalkMe Standardcontent ist noch offen, ob es wieder Zugriff mittels WalkMe auf Standardlerninhalte geben wird, √§hnlich dem Extended Scenario im SAP Companion.

Empfehlungen f√ºr den √úbergang

Mike Fritz empfiehlt eine parallele Nutzung beider Systeme w√§hrend der √úbergangszeit (Test&Go Live). Neue Inhalte sollten schrittweise mit WalkMe Learning Arc erstellt werden, w√§hrend bestehende SAP Enable Now Inhalte weiterhin genutzt werden k√∂nnen. Da der SAP Enable Now Producer bis 2030 unterst√ºtzt wird, steht ausreichend Zeit f√ºr eine vollst√§ndige Migration zur Verf√ºgung.

Strategische Migrationsentscheidungen

Mike Fritz bot konkrete Handlungsempfehlungen: Er empfahl, die SAP Enable Now Workspaces aufzur√§umen und nur noch das zu migrieren, was valide ist. Dabei sollte im Prinzip die Granularit√§t beibehalten werden, sofern sie Sinn macht. Wenn das interne Wissensmanagement in Zielsystemen organisiert ist (z.B. ein Ariba Workspace, ein SuccessFactors Workspace), dann sollte das eins-zu-eins beibehalten werden. Wenn es zielgruppenspezifisch organisiert ist und festgestellt wird, dass mit den neuen M√∂glichkeiten im WalkMe Lernportal eine Konsolidierung einfacher w√§re, geht das genauso.

Fazit und Ausblick

Die Live-Demonstration des Potenzials der KI-nativen Herangehensweise f√ºr die Content-Erstellung und die nahtlose Integration in bestehende Arbeitsabl√§ufe zeigten beeindruckende M√∂glichkeiten auf. entry.title: S/4HANA is not an update ‚Äì Why logistics determines the fate of migration
entry.content:
The year 2027 is fast approaching, and in boardrooms, unease is growing regarding the end of SAP ECC maintenance. However, while much is being discussed about database technologies and new Fiori interfaces, the real battleground is often overlooked: operational logistics and the supply chain.

When observing failed or delayed projects, the cause rarely lies in financial accounting. The problems explode where the physical business meets the digital system.
The devil is in the details: when "simplification" suddenly means complexity.

When companies take the plunge and move to S/4HANA, the buzzword "simplification" is often used. The goal is to streamline processes and simplify data models. This is strategically sound. However, for operational implementation in materials management (MM) and sales and distribution (SD), this "simplification" often means that logics that have been valid for years suddenly become obsolete.

A classic example that causes confusion in many projects is source identification. In the ECC world, the source list was often the law. It rigidly controlled whether an information record or contract was even considered by the MRP.

With S/4HANA's "Simplification," source determination has changed noticeably in many scenarios, depending on the activated MRP logic (e.g., MRP Live / "Simplified Sourcing") and customization.
In these situations, S/4HANA can use valid vendors, info records, or contracts even if no explicit order book entry exists as a "gatekeeper."
Important: Where a material/plant is subject to source list requirements, the order book remains binding.

Anyone who uses a "lift-and-shift" approach here, relying on the order book to maintain control (or who habitually uses it everywhere), is in for a surprise: Suddenly, sources are accessed that were thought to be "muted" in the old system, or the prioritization between quotation and simple procurement works differently than expected. This isn't a system error‚Äîit's the new standard logic. But you have to understand it to manage planning effectively.
Interfaces don't forgive "simplification."

This level of detail is also required where S/4HANA extends beyond its own system boundaries. The internal simplification of the data model (e.g., in the business partner approach or in inventory management) often clashes with the reality of the connected subsystems.

Whether it's warehouse management systems (non-SAP WMS) or complex EDI connections to suppliers: the interfaces (IDocs) must "translate" this new logic. An experienced eye for message control and integration points is crucial here. After all, what good is the most sophisticated new planning logic in S/4 if the WMS can't interpret the changed partner/master data logic (business partners/CVI) or the altered inventory and status logic (e.g., inventory qualifications/status transitions) ? After go-live, this doesn't mean a minor error, but rather operational standstill.
Why "generalists" are no longer sufficient.

In the current market phase, many companies are resorting to generalists to fill resource gaps. However, S/4HANA requires specialists who have a deep understanding of process integration ‚Äì from procurement (MM) to shipping (LE/SD).

It's no longer enough to simply program hundreds of Z-reports to patch process gaps ("back to standard"). The real challenge lies in configuring the new standard to serve the company. You have to understand how the new standard works ‚Äì and where you need to judiciously expand it to maintain a competitive edge.
In short: Quality in the preparation phase saves on the budget for follow-up work.

The budget for S/4HANA is often primarily allocated to licenses and infrastructure. However, the ROI is determined at the foundation: in the clean migration of logistics processes and the stable integration of interfaces.

Companies would be well advised to invest not only in project management, but also in experts who understand the subtle differences between ECC and S/4HANA at the field level. Those who cut corners here and forgo senior expertise will pay twice as much later ‚Äì through process disruptions, costly rework, and planning that misses the mark.

entry.title: Re: How to Migrate Multi-Level WBS Hierarchy in SAP S/4HA...
entry.content:
Dear @MohamedKharbouch,

In Public Cloud the supported way to mass-create an Enterprise Project together with its WBS structure is the Migration Cockpit object Enterprise Project NOT a standalone WBS element object in isolation. SAP explicitly points to Enterprise Project for migrating project general data + WBS and for mass creation in Project Control

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3283851

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3448643

Question 1. How to migrate multi-level WBS hierarchies

Use the Enterprise Project migration object:

  • Create a migration project in Migrate Your Data Migration Cockpit
  • Select Enterprise Project
  • Maintain the WBS rows in that template with:
    • WBS Element ID (unique)
    • Parent / Superior WBS Element ID
    • Sort Number

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/d5699934e7004d048c4801b552f3b013/444fa56a65a84453bbf5e306d754a3b3.html?version=2508.500&profile=20597362

SAP confirms that Parent WBS Element ID is what makes different hierarchies possible and that Sort Number controls the order of arrangement within a hierarchy

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3128304

Practical implications:

  • Every non-top WBS must have Parent WBS Element ID = exact WBS ID of its parent same formatting, no extra spaces, consistent capitalization
  • Maintain a positive Sort Number and use it consistently so the system can arrange siblings deterministically and in practice, it also helps avoid random processing order issues

What you describe is consistent with a Migration Cockpit hierarchy dependency check the tool or the underlying API processing requires that referenced higher level nodes already exist when it validates/creates the dependent nodes. SAP documents this generically as the records that do not exist at a higher level in the hierarchy family of errors for example message: DMC_RT_MSG616

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2899371

Question 2. Is there a required migration sequence?

Yes, top-down is the safe and SAP-aligned approach:

  1. Enterprise Project header / general data, if applicable in your template
  2. Top-level WBS (no parent)
  3. Next level WBS (parent exists)
  4. Continue until the deepest level

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Manufacturing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602
entry.content:
Hello and welcome to the latest SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release. We are kicking off the year with a significant wave of enhancement in the area of manufacturing and it would be great if you join the ride!  Annette and I are happy to guide you through the latest enhancements and innovations. First things first, here is the release highlight video: 

Video#1: Release Highlights Overview

 

Production Engineering 

New Features for Production Engineering, including AI

We are proud to introduce our new AI-assisted production routing proposal and copy routing feature. Production engineers and master data specialists know that creating new production routings involves a lot of repetitive data entry, especially when you are creating data for similar products. To solve this issue and speed up the process, we are introducing AI-assisted production routing proposals. 

AI-assisted production routing proposal and copy routing feature

The AI engine analyzes existing production routings to find similar routings based on material name, description, and bill of material. Instead of starting from scratch, users can copy and adapt the most relevant routing. This innovation directly translates into significant time savings, a lower risk of data entry errors, and greater consistency across your master data. It helps your teams work faster and smarter. 

This demo was given during our Manufacturing Early Release Webinar: 

 

Video#2: Demo AI-assisted production routing proposal and copy routing

‚ÄãAs a prerequisite, you need to enable the related ISLM scenario. For information on setting up the ISLM scenario, see this blog post.

New Configuration Activity

Additionally, we are introducing a new configuration activity for the Responsible Capacity Planner Group. Use the new configuration activity Determine Capacity Planning to define the person or group of people who are responsible for planning capacities.

New configuration activity Determine Capacity Planning

If you want to find out about what is coming for product lifecycle management in the Cloud, please refer to this blog post on SAP Integrated Product Development.

 

New Features for Production Planning & Execution, including AI  

The next innovations are particularly relevant for production planners and manufacturing supervisors who are looking to streamline their daily operations, gain deeper insights, and leverage the power of automation and AI. Lets explore the key highlights that will help you optimize your end-to-end processes.


Manage Material Coverage - Navigation to Related Apps

The Manage Material Coverage app has been enhanced to include additional navigation options. These new links provide you with fast and easy access to detailed information on materials and MRP elements directly from your worklist.

 

Manage Material Coverage - Navigation to Related Apps

This enhancement helps material planners and MRP controllers to quickly analyze situations and make informed decisions without navigating through multiple screens, which significantly streamlines the material analysis process.

To help you analyze and resolve coverage issues more quickly, navigation options were added for the following MRP elements:

Receipt Elements:

  • Purchase Order
  • Purchase Requisition
  • Planned Order
  • Stock Transport Order
  • Stock Transport Requisition
  • Stock

Requirement Elements:

  • Sales Order
  • Delivery
  • Order Reservation
  • Dependent Requirement
  • Planned Independent Requirement
  • Stock Transfer Order Release
  • Stock Transfer Requisition Release

This demo was given during our Manufacturing Early Release Webinar: 

 

Video#3: Manage Material Coverage - Navigation to Related Apps


Capacity Scheduling Table

With this feature, you can now view a "Missing Components" popup by clicking the Missing Components icon within the Capacity Scheduling Table.

Capacity Scheduling Table 

This provides production planners and schedulers with immediate visibility into material shortages that could impact the production schedule. This direct access to critical information allows for quicker problem resolution and more resilient production planning.

Manage Work Center Capacity

The following enhancements were done with the latest CFDs and also the 2602 main release: 

  • 2508.1: View the Customer name and ID through the Customer column. You can view this column by clicking the Settings wheel in the Items table in the Operations section.
  • 2508.1: View the Consolidated Shift Capacity and the Remaining Capacity. These columns can be viewed by clicking the Table icon in the Overview section.
  • 2602: View the Utilization in the form of a line micro chart instead of a bar micro chart when you load the app. This enables you to visualize data for a maximum of 750 data points based on the Evaluation Horizon instead of the 28 days limit for the bar micro chart.

Manage Work Center Capacity

For further details and demo you can navigate to this 2508.1 blog post: Enhancing Manufacturing Excellence: What's New in ... - SAP Community

Review Order Progress - Order Selection and Views

In the Review Order Progress - Multilevel View app, the filtering options for order numbers have been improved. Now, depending on the document type you select, different filter fields are provided as mandatory to ensure the order number you specify matches the document type.

Review Order Progress - Order Selection and Views

Furthermore, you can now create and save personalized views of the order components table, allowing you to access your preferred layout and settings quickly.

Check out this demo from our 2602 Manufacturing Early Release Webinar: 

 

Video#4: Review Order Progress - Order Selection and Views

External Scheduling for Planned Orders

This feature enables you to update your S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system with schedule data from an external scheduler. This is crucial for organizations that use specialized, third-party tools for detailed production scheduling. It ensures that data remains consistent between your planning tools and your system of record, providing a single source of truth for your production plan.


Manage Production Orders - Production Planning and Operations Agent

This feature introduces the ability to start the Production Planning and Operations Agent directly from the worklist of the Manage Production Orders app. A new "Release" button is now available, enabling you to release your production orders assisted by agentic AI technology. This innovation helps production supervisors automate and optimize the order release process, improving efficiency and reducing manual workload.

Manage Production Orders - Production Planning and Operations Agent

What can the agent do for you so far: 

  • Assisting the production planners and supervisors in releasing up to 20 production orders at a time.
  • The agent automates prerequisite checks necessary for releasing production orders, including component availability and alternatives as well as work center capacity checks.
  • The agent also proposes rescheduling when the prerequisites for release are not met.
  • Once all criteria are met, the planner can confirm the proposed order changes, and the agent will complete the production order release.

This feature will not automatically be available in your system but requires that you activate the feature Release with Production Planning and Operations Agent  (PP_FIO_SFC_AI297_RELEASEAGENT) in the configuration activity Activate Features. 

Watch this demo that was given during the 2602 Manufacturing Early Release Webinar:

 

Video#5: Manage Production Orders - Production Planning and Operations Agent

Working with AI-assisted features like this is a key part of our innovation strategy. Please note that to access this generative AI feature, an additional entitlement may be required. Before enabling such features, ensure you adhere to your company's compliance framework regarding the usage of generative AI. You should also acknowledge that the AI-Assisted Smart summarization does not provide the technical capabilities to support the collection, processing, and storage of personal data. Please consult your account executive for more information.

Combined Order Enablement 

A significant efficiency improvement is now available for discrete manufacturing. This feature enables you to combine identical operations from different production orders into a single, consolidated production order. The combination can include either individual operations or entire orders.

Combined Order Enablement

This process, often known as order combination, helps reduce setup times and manufacturing costs by processing similar requirements together. This innovation runs under the new scope item 7TO. 

This demo was presented during the 2602 Manufacturing Early Release Webinar: 

 

Video#6: Combined Order Enablement 

Feel free to follow us in the SAP community and on LinkedIn to not miss any updates.

Watch the replays of our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 Early Release Series! 

From January 12-16, 2026, we hosted a series of compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you.  You can find the recordings of your past sessions on SAP Learning. As a partner, you will find the recording and presentation for Manufacturing as well as other topics of interest via the Empowering SAP partners site.

 Find all our assets  

The release 2602 showcases more 130 innovation highlights across the portfolio. Check out our release document for all the details!

We at Cloud ERP and SCM Product Success offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Click on the enablement wheel below and check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you:

entry.title: SuccessFactors Recruiting: Enhancement Request for Multiple Document Uploads in Interview Central
entry.content:
Hello HCM Community!

I wanted to share an SAP Influence enhancement request related to SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting ‚Äì Interview Central and see if others across HCM teams are running into the same challenge.

At the moment, Interview Central only allows one document to be uploaded under Upload Interview Notes. There‚Äôs no ability to multi-select files or upload additional documents once a note is added. For organizations using structured interview forms, panel interviews, or multiple interviewer feedback documents, this creates extra administrative work and inconsistent record-keeping.

We‚Äôve submitted an enhancement request asking SAP to support multiple document uploads within Interview Central, similar to other attachment areas across SuccessFactors.

If this limitation affects your recruiting, HRIS, or talent teams, I‚Äôd really appreciate your vote and/or comment on the request:
Improvement Request | Enable Multiple Document Uploads in Interview Central ‚Äì Interview Notes 

Additional customer support and use cases help give this request more visibility with the product team. Thanks in advance, and happy to connect with others who are navigating the same workaround today.

entry.title: No Data Returned in CDS I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost After Filling Parameters (Production Order Cos
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I hope you are doing well.

I am currently working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, and I am trying to build a production cost analysis in Power BI using CDS views as the data source.

My objective is to analyze production order costs by activity, such as:

  • Labor hours (man-hours)

  • Machine hours

  • Utility-related costs (energy, water, etc.)

  • Actual vs planned/target costs associated with manufacturing or process orders

The goal is to extract this information via a CDS view and consume it in Power BI.

At the moment, I am using the CDS view:

  • I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost

When I try to preview this CDS, the system requires the following parameters:

  • Ledger

  • Fiscal Year Period From

  • Fiscal Year Period To

  • Currency Role

Even after entering valid values for all these parameters, no data is returned in the preview.

Because of this behavior, I am not sure whether:

  • This CDS requires additional CO configuration (e.g. settlement, period-end closing, or cost posting prerequisites),

  • The parameters (ledger, fiscal year/period, or currency role) must be provided in a specific way,

  • Or if this CDS is not intended to be consumed directly for detailed production order cost analysis.

My questions are:

  1. Has anyone successfully used I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost and faced a similar issue with no data returned?

  2. Are there any known prerequisites (e.g. cost postings, activity confirmations, period-end processes) required for this CDS to return data?

  3. Are there alternative CDS views recommended to analyze costs associated with production or process orders, especially with a breakdown by activities (labor, machine) and cost components?

Any guidance, experience, or best practices would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you very much in advance for your support.

Best regards,
Sergio

entry.title: Re: No Data Returned in CDS I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost...
entry.content:
first check if your role has the proper authorization

this is what sap is checking

define role I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost {

grant

select

on

I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost

where ( OrderCategory, OrderType, Plant ) ?= aspect pfcg_auth ( C_AFKO_AWA, AUTYP, AUFART, WERKS, ACTVT = '03' )

and ( CompanyCode ) ?= aspect pfcg_auth( F_BKPF_BUK, BUKRS, ACTVT = '03' )

and ( OrderType ) ?= aspect pfcg_auth( K_ORDER, AUFART, CO_ACTION = '3028' );

}
